title: Promptotyping: A Qualitative Analysis of LLM-Assisted Development
subtitle: Learning from Practice-Based Experiments
abstract: This paper presents Promptotyping, a flexible methodology for LLM-assisted software development, through qualitative analysis of real-world experiments. Rather than proposing theoretical frameworks or quantitative metrics, we document patterns observed across multiple implementation cases. The methodology emerged organically from practice, revealing that successful LLM collaboration depends more on expert guidance and clear documentation than on rigid processes. Through case studies including the Stefan Zweig Digital annotation tool and the self-reflexive development of this methodology, we identify key principles: documentation-first development, optional phase structures, critical expert involvement, and natural progression from exploratory to systematic approaches. Our findings suggest that the most effective methodologies are those that practitioners adapt to their specific contexts rather than follow prescriptively.
